comments.commentBody: Glad to see you're OK with a country preaching that we're the devil and calling for the obliteration of a country that promotes our core principles of freedom for all should be developing weapons of mass destruction. I mean why should they be demonized? They're helping Syria massacre her own people, they're mullahs live life to the fullest while they're own people suffer, its leadership spurned the wishes of its own people who were duped into believing that election results would be honored, they suppress the rights of Bahais, women, other minorities. You should be very proud.
We used to have places for people like Gingrich here, but Reagan closed them when anti-psychotic drugs became available.

People should be very concerned that a US president doesn't understand the distinction between policy and guaranteeing a constitution right.

He's claiming to "accommodate" the Church, but in fact he's "accommodating" the constitution. He should know better.

From the article:

The situation at the macro level is, if anything, even more transformational. The Chinese have largely taken over Piraeus, Greece’s main port, with an eye to make it a conduit for shipping goods into Europe. Qatar is looking to invest $5 billion in various projects in Greece, including tourism infrastructure. Other, relatively flush Europeans are trying to make “Greece the Florida of Europe,” Theodore Pelagidis, a Greek economist at the University of Piraeus, told me, referring in particular to plans to turn islands into expensive retirement homes for wealthy people from other parts of the continent. Whether or not the country pays its debts, he went on, other nations and foreign companies “now understand the Greek government is powerless, so in the future they will take over viable assets and run parts of the country by themselves.”

The second sentence of my comment:
"Capitalism IN ITS MOST PRIMITIVE FORM: theft." (emphasis mine)

What readers see when confronted with printed words on a page never ceases to amaze me.

Social media are great for verbal people, but probably not so much for those who don't express themselves so much in words. It doesn't have to be for everyone to be valid, of course, but it does miss a big chunk of the population, and of life, for that reason.

I'm no fan of Santorum (very far from it!)... but that photo is just a snapshot. I watched some of his speech (couldn't get through it all!), and they did smile occasionally.

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/video/rick-santorums-full-speech-cpac-201...

Mr. Stein,

Your perception of Mr. Santorum's wife and daughter is widely shared. These were not the usual smiling, confident visages one expects to see on the faces of the family members of a candidate who is winning. While we can only speculate about why they appear so dour at the moment of victory while standing among people who are supportive, the widely circulated picture will only serve to reinforce doubts about Rick Santorum.

Being traditionalists, there is among Santorumistas an adherence to the old practice of shunning and even not speaking to those who don't agree, rather than engaging in lively, considered debate. So in private life the costs of disagreement are devastating, and mightily effective in coercing social cohesiveness. Also interesting is the quietly sanctioned rule-bending in areas such as contraceptive use and marriage annulment that allows the appearance of group membership to remain intact without overt disagreement with dogma.

I know I am being subjective, but I saw a news report of a Santorum victory speech with his wife and daughter in the background. I am not intending to be cruel but these two women looked like the two most unhappy spouse and child I have ever seen at such an event.

His wife seemed tense with a capital T and his daughter, who seemed in her late teens to early adult looked scared, pensive and had a distinct frown. They looked like they were both coerced to be there, and at least to me had the expressions one would expect from a hostage.

I don't like Santorum but I had never seen his family before and I was struck and the total lack of joy in their faces. I was almost expecting to see his daughter hold a note with the words "HELP ME!" Again, I am not trying to be mean, and perhaps given what I perceive to be his absurdly extremist views on sexuality I was reading things into it. However, my initial gut reaction was "What is wrong with these poor woman?" They seemed under duress, and my interpretation is that it was not from the scene, but from having a man with such crazy beliefs as a husband and father.

Santorum isn't electable and now it is his time to be exposed as an extremist fraud. All themes candidates seem like ducks at a shooting gallery in an amusement park, when one by one they pass before the public view to be shot down.

By the way, I think Callista stays so transfixed on Newt because what she actually is seeing is a Tiffany window. She's window shopping

tsk,tsk, envy and and constant blame won't restore society, someone's 9 houses had to be built by other someones and gave them a chance to make a living. We cann't all be Rockefellers , we can only hope that this
time of Progressive rule, does not destroy the rest of our society.

Ah David Brooks is 50. I am not criticizing that, merely creating perspective. Just old enough to recall the significant breakups of ethnic neighborhoods and the dramatic decline of the rust belt. I am from Michigan and I recall the rather dramtic decline of so many cohesive neighborhhoods in the North. And when so many moved South, I also witnessed the change there as well. Yes David, the economic changes that have occured since 1962 were dramatic and completely changed the fabric of so many communities. Many are only just now stabilizing.

And so on to his main thesis which I guess is that no one totally understand what has happened and than largely undercuts the main theme of the progressive side.
He discounts Murray but has already fallen into the mythology trap.The period of time before 1962 was not a period where everyone was content and satisfied. The US basked in a strong economy due to WWII. But strains were developing. Post Nam the economy fell into a recession and then Reagan and the GOP proceeded with the trickle down theory.

Any sociologist will have to admit that peolpe without work tend to remove themselves from society. People without hope also do that.

Whatever the causes, the economy has been largely pitiful for millions of Americans since 1962. The country is still adjusting if only the right wing will allow average Americans to prosper despie the desire of average wealthy people to have a nth house or yacht or additional offshore bank account.

Your link didn't work. Is it correct?

I agree with you about how great this kind of life can be. The nuclear family isn't the be-all and end-all of everything for everybody, although like everything, when it works well, it's great.

The only problem I see with that is when health problems arise. We need to find a way to get "family" status in the eyes of the law when it comes to making medical decisions and being privy to medical information of our "out-law partners."

The problem is that Apple couldn't bring production back to the US right now even if it tried. All of the necessary manufacturing infrastructure has disappeared (i.e. components manufacturers), so even if final assembly was done in the US, it would be using components manufactured elsewhere. You're talking about rebuilding an entire industry, not just assembling a single product.

And also keep in mind that since Apple is now a worlwide brand selling products worldwide, it doesn't really make much sense for it to move any manufacturing capacity back to the US either. It's fastest growing markets are all non-US markets such as China and India, which means that ten years down the road, US sales are probably going to be only a small percentage of Apple's overall sales.

Mr. Levine, the story of Rev. White's mother is making me cry. I would die of grief if I spent 20 years not knowing what happened to my son.
I appreciate that you give your students time to think about and absorb what they are seeing. My experience of field trips is that the school children are rushed through things so fast they don't even know what they are looking at. I went to see some of the greatest art work in the world, Roman Art from the Louvre, in Oklahoma City, where busload after busload of children were raced through the various rooms of statues, mosiacs, and paintings. The groups of children spent less than 5 minutes in each room, The schools alloted so little time to see this amazing art.

Based on the results and polls to date, the Republican Party must think this is true.  Let's not vote for the candidate that has the only workable tax and energy plans.  Let's not vote for the candidate that can actually beat President O'bama.  Let's not vote for the candidate that has set and achieved goals for the advancement of conservatism.  Newt has done more to advance the cause of conservatism than anyone in the presidential race.  He not only ended 40 years of Democratic control in the House, he ended Democratic control of southern states like Georgia too.  Republicans forget how much Newt has done for conservatism.  Regardless of how he did it and whether he made a few mistakes along the way, he accomplished his goals.  For example, he didn't quit until Republicans controlled the house.  It took him over 12 years to achieve this goal.  (Funny, how people are so quick to conclude that Newt quit the speakership because he was scared he didn't have the votes to win.  How difficult is it to understand that he would rather step down than risk the Republicans losing control of the house.)  Unfortunately, people just don’t get that the one and only reason Newt has ever done and will ever do anything is for conservatism, not individualism.

Domingo Tavella has never heard of the term tax incidence before. Either that, or they believe corporations are "people" and those "people" pay the corporate income tax, as opposed to the shareholders of the company.

We have "conservatie" politicians in the United States, but most are servants of corporate interests and not conservative at all. If you want to see REAL conservatism, go to Japan. A stable society is valued over almost everything else. It has its good points and bad points. After living in Japan for two decades and relocating back to the States in the age of Glenn Beck, Sarah Palin and Rick Santorum, Japan's good points look better and better to me!
Guys, I think Mr. Charles Richards was kidding.

Ah, the miracle of aggregation. Seriously, it's the standard demographics way of saying this. I can't think of a substitute off the top of my head, plus, a newspaper article is supposed to use standard expressions.

We're talking about an exemption not about eliminating the entire policy.

The government policy would exempt organizations from paying for insurance on faith-based grounds. Why? Not because some old men say it should be so but rather because their right to do so is a protected right.

Do you know how many exemptions the Obama Administration grants on a monthly basis? I'm sure the grounds on which those exemptions are based are a lot less significant that this one.
A lot of the people responding are well over 55 and are happy enough with how their lives are working out.

If this WAS an Iranian attempt at retaliation against Israel for its assassinations of Iranian nuclear weapons engineers, it suggests Iran is incompetent when it comes to strategy.

1) The targets they chose were not strategic and not even compellingly symbolic.

2) Execution was woefully lacking.

3) And why would they risk offending India, one of their few remaining significant trade partners?

Xerxes wept.
That's because those Nobel Prize winners were Jewish Germans later dispersed by Hitler around the globe if they avoided capture by the regime.
Actually Nazi Germany had far more Nobel Prize winners than Israel.   Bigger and better technical advances.   Bad guess on a national parameter.

The bombings or attempted bombings are strikingly similar to the attacks on Iranian scientists, except in this case, there were no serious injuries or death. Can you say 'Mossad'? For an instructive story about misleading 'attacks' meant to prompt war, see "The Quiet American" with Michael Caine.

Exactly, it's called the Hawthorne effect.  Computer mania in classrooms is part of the No Lemming Left Behind program.  Because administrators, school board members and parents fear what they don't understand, they clutch it to their chests and pay through the nose.  The tool replaces thought processes and we're left with kids who think the world is flat.  And why not? They've never seen or worked with a globe. And forget reading.  It's so yesterday, so much wasted concentration, so much struggling with comprehension, so much patience.  Point and click is the way to go when the Tool Rules.

Inbreeding is very pronounced in pure bred dogs. There are millions of German Shepard Dogs today all descended from one dog named Horand von Grafrath that died around 1900. This is true for most dog races, so Winnie can have a lot of Tago in her. Inbreeding is not specific to dogs as this is how all domesticated animal breeds were created.
For example mating Tago with his own offspring produces a dog with 3/4 Tago genes, mating that offspring with Tago produces a pup with 7/8 genes from Tago etc.
This is the work of CIA to incite India against Iran. Period. India will not buy this.
